sen.j: 瓢箪小僧（ひょうたんこぞう）とは、瓢箪が変化して生まれた日本の妖怪である。
sen.e: Hyotankozo refers to Japanese specter, mutated from a gourd.
A Hyotan-kozo (literally, a calabash or bottle gourd boy) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was transmuted from a calabash or bottle gourd.

sen.j: 付喪神の一種とされる。
sen.e: It is considered as a sort of a Tsukumo-gami (gods to a variety of things).
It is considered to be a kind of tsukumogami (a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive).

sen.j: 頭部が瓢箪となった人のような姿で、鳥山石燕の「画図百器徒然袋」に乳鉢坊と共に描かれている。
sen.e: With Nyubobachi, Hyotankozo is portrayed in a human-like figure whose head is a gourd in Sekien TORIYAMA's "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idlenss).

Sekien TORIYAMA's "Gazu Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Illustrated Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami) portrays the Hyotankozo in a human-like figure whose head is a bottle gourd, along with a Nyubachibo (literally, a mortar [a bowl-shaped vessel] bonze).

sen.j: 古来より日本では、瓢箪のように中が空洞になったものには霊魂がこもりやすいといわれる。
sen.e: In Japan, from ancient times, it is said that the spirit may easily stay in a object with a cavity, such as a gourd.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: From ancient times, Japanese people have believed that spirits and souls may easily stay in a hollow object, such as a bottle gourd.

sen.j: 瓢箪を吊るすと病気にならない、庭に瓢箪を作ると変事が起きるなどの呪術的な俗信がある。
sen.e: There are magical folk beliefs, such as hanging gourd may prevent diseases and growing gourds in the yard may cause a disaster.

sen.j: そうしたものに悪い霊が瓢箪に取り憑いて妖怪となったものが、瓢箪小僧ともいう。
sen.e: The gourd haunted by such bad spirits becomes a specter, which may be called Hyotankozo.
The gourd which was possessed by an evil spirit became a yokai, which may also be called the Hyotankozo.

sen.j: 茂みの中から突然現れて、人を驚かせるとの説もある。
sen.e: Some say that it appears suddenly out of a thicket and frightens people.
